titleStmt.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 18 July 1863

titleStmt.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 18 July 1863
titleStmt.author: William B. Anderson

notesStmt.note:
Letter of 1 July 1863
Letter of 18 July 1863
William B. Anderson's letter dated June 18, 1863 from Cincinnati and addressed to his wife Louisa is written in ink on one side of a loose sheet of paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 9.0 inches tall (19 x 23 cm). The left edge of the sheet is slightly ragged, while the other three edges are clean, suggesting that the sheet was torn from a notepad or bound notebook. It appears originally to have been folded once crosswise and twice lengthwise. At this writing, the ink appears brown and the paper off-white (cream). A .5-inch by .5-inch (1.3 x 1.3 cm) embossed printer's mark appears in the upper lefthand corner of the sheet, 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) from the top edge and .25 inches (0.6 cm) from the left edge. There is no image, only the text "OWEN & HURLEBUT So Lee MASS." (see illustrations).

projectDesc.p: In this particular letter on 18 July 1863 from William B. Anderson to his wife, Mary Louisa, Anderson is brief and shares only trivial news of his ship and crew with her. A loving father, he also asks her to kiss their children for him and for them to be good. Obviously, Anderson was very much in a hurry and while some words are misspelled, others are abbreviated. Punctuation also seems to be the last thing on his mind as he writes this letter because it is seldom used.

As with all but two of the letters, this particular letter is written from Cincinnati, a thriving town in 1863, located on the Ohio River, where Anderson traveled on his steamship transporting various goods between St. Louis and Pittsburgh.

In this particular letter, Anderson laments that he has not recently received any letters from his wife and tells her that he is disappointed. He also shares with her the state of his crew, including illnesses, which he blames for being unable to visit her mother. On this trip, his cargo is sutlers goods, which are traditionally goods intended for military use. These particular goods were put into many small packages that kept Anderson and his crew busy loading them on the wharf until late at night. Anderson also shares with his wife the state of Elias, one of the members of his crew. Anderson took him to see Dave Indkins, who was caring for him.

Anderson promises to write to Mary Louisa from either Evansville or Nashville, but curiously enough, all of the letters we have worked with until this point are either from Cincinnati, Pittsburgh, or St. Louis. He tells his wife to kiss the children for him and wishes them well. He shares with her that he wrote to Russell and that he sent a statement for his finances. He also tells her to get what sugar she would like from him.
Anderson gives excuses several times that he is very busy and in the closing of the letter, he apologizes for any errors in the letters.

This particular letter allows us to put into context just some of his daily work as well as some of the goods that he carried along the Ohio River. This format of the Anderson letters allows for long-term preservation and availability to scholars of war-era letters, riverboat enthusiasts, or historians.

Anderson's letters to his wife are valuable to history as a primary source of life in the 1860's as a riverboat captain. The XML coding in the transcription of the letters makes the letters available to a wide audience when they cannot see the actual physical letter and also, it provides information to the reader about some subjects raised by Anderson himself.

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of the Anderson letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription, with supplemental information allowing for semi-modernized, corrected, regularized, or expanded views included as the values of attributes associated with various elements. Accordingly, abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underscoring, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed or tagged as they appear in the original manuscripts. Regularized versions of all names and referring strings have been encoded as the values of "reg" attributes. Standard format values for all dates have been encoded in "value" attributes.

Corrections and emendations in Anderson's hand have been encoded as cancelations and interlinear or marginal additions. In a few cases, omitted text has been supplied by the editors for the sake of clarity and encoded with the TEI <supplied> element.

The following structural elements of the letters are also encoded: opener (including salutation and dateline), body, lines, paragraphs, pages, and closers (including salutation and signature). Notes and postscripts are identified as such.
The critical apparatus used in particular views of the letters is explained at the bottom of each view.
To view the project's complete markup guidelines, click here.

At the time of publication (6 June 2006), the XML and XSL files related to this edition were stored in an XML publishing system operated by Humanities Information Systems (HIS), College of Humanities, The Ohio State University. For more information about HIS, see http://his.osu.edu/. Most image, audio, and video files linked to, or embedded in, this edition via <figure> elements were stored in the Media Manager system maintained by the Colleges of Arts and Sciences of The Ohio State University. For more information about the Media Manager, see https://mediamanager.osu.edu/.

refsDecl.p: The XML files that constitute this edition of the William B. Anderson letters are named according the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: WBA_YYYYMMDD.xml. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars. If the year, month, or date on which a letter was written could not be determined, the appropriate part of the filename is rendered with 0s. XSL style sheet documents are named with the prefix "WBA" followed by an underscore and a descriptive phrase (e.g., "WBA_diplomatic.xsl).

In general, this edition follows the Text Encoding Initiative's Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, XML-compatible edition P4. For more information about TEI P4, see http://www.tei-c.org/P4X/. To facilitate embedding or linking to image, audio, and video files, this edition supplements the Text Encoding Initiative's DTD by adding a URL attribute to the <xref> element and an MMID (i.e., Media Manager ID) attribute to the <pb> element. The values of the MMID attribute in <pb> elements and the file IDs in the URL attribute of <xref> elements that link to, or embed, image, audio, and video files contained in the Media Manager are generated by the Media Manager application.

bibl.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 18 July 1863

div1.p: Anderson shares with his wife the status of his crew and currently what cargo he is carrying, though he does not share with her his destination, he promises to write to her from either Evansville or Nashville. He also tells her that he has prepared the finances and taxes for Russell and for her to get any sugar she would like from him. He asks her to kiss his children for him and wishes them well while he is gone. He also apologizes for mistakes in spelling and other errors.
Previous letter 5 July 1863 Next Letter 31 July 1863

We are on the eve of
leaving for Nashville2 “prospects good”
I have not read any letter from you since
I wrote and am disappointed! Ella3 was here
yesterday & today your mother is well as
usual Elias4 is sick and I could not leave
the boat long enough to see your mother
Our Cargo Consists of Sutlers goods5 and
as they are in so many small pkgs it
Kept Joe6 & I both bussily engaged all the
time on the wharf till late at night
we have no Passengers but are full of Frt
& if we are successful will make a good
trip. I have been very well & all on
board are well except Elias I got Dr Dave
Indkins7 to See him and I think he will get well
the water appears to dissagree with him
I think he is mending now I will
write you from Evansville or Nashville
again Kiss all the children and tell them
to be good I wrote to Russell8 to day
& Sent him a statement of My income
Tax to Pay it? I am in a great hurry
and have not time to write long
get what sugar you want from Russell
PS Excuse all Errors Write often

div1.head: Notes
div1.note: 1. Mary Louisa Fischgens (1837-1911) and William B. Anderson were married September 15, 1853 in Cincinnati, Ohio.History of Allegheny County 298.
2. Nashville is located on the Cumberland River in the northern region of the state of Tennessee. Nashville
3. Though no official record of "Ella" could be located, she is mentioned in many of the letters and within their context, she appears to be a family member or close friend of the family.
4. Though no official record of "Elias" could be located, he is mentioned subsequently in letters 15 and 16.
5. Sutlers goods were the everyday necessities such as food and tools made available to the soldiers in the war. Sutlers: An integral part of the Civil War .
8. Possibly the same John Russell referred to in Biographical Review as “a prominent merchant on Liberty Street [in Pittsburgh] for many years” (205).

bibl.title: Biographical review; v. 24, containing life sketches of leading citizens of Pittsburg and the vicinity, Pennsylvania
Sutlers: An integral part of the Civil War
